content:
• Wednesday, July 8, 2015
  • AABA

    Yahoo launches daily fantasy sports business

    • Yahoo (YHOO -2.6%) is jumping into the daily fantasy sports arena, a potentially lucrative field that is getting more crowded as big media firms pick out partners.
    • The company launched its site to host daily and weekly games where fans assemble rosters and earn points based on game performance in those short-term competitions.
    • An estimated 57M participants in the U.S. and Canada average spending $465 a year on fees and materials related to the short-term fantasy games, Ipsos says. That adds up to about $2.6B in entry fees, and potentially hundreds of millions in revenue for Yahoo.
    • The space is dominated now by FanDuel and DraftKings -- the former of which has major investments from Comcast as well as KKR and Shamrock Ventures, and the latter with its own millions in venture funding and a relationship with ESPN. Both companies have been valued at $1B.
    • Yahoo's not starting from scratch, though: Daily games are dependent on quick and voluminous data, which the company has been offering sports fans for years.
    • Previously: Blistering pace of growth at FanDuel (Jan. 13 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 10:47 PM | 10 Comments
  • S

    Sprint suffers worst one-day loss since November

    • On a down day for U.S. markets at large and the sector in particular, Sprint (NYSE:S) still led telecom decliners, -8.3% (its biggest one-day drop in eight months) on a day where NYSE trading was interrupted for more than three hours.
    • Analyst Craig Moffett thinks the government may take a different stance than it did before on a merger between Sprint and T-Mobile (NASDAQ:TMUS) -- if Sprint "really is in severe financial distress, as we think they will be within a relatively short period of time."
    • A Sprint/T-Mobile tie-up, though, wouldn't happen until after the next presidential election, if at all, he said.
    • Asked about merger talk between T-Mobile and Dish Network (NASDAQ:DISH), meanwhile, Moffett thinks that's "unlikely" and "not about the business synergy between two businesses."
    • "Although it was touted as Dish buying T-Mobile, it would really be T-Mobile buying Dish's spectrum through a complicated transaction."
    • This spring, Moffett has pointed to cash burn in saying that if T-Mobile goes to another acquirer, "Sprint's in a world of hurt" and running out of good options. "At the current rate of cash burn, the company will run out of cash in a year."
    • Previously: T-Mobile and Dish Network: Other options, other suitors (Jun. 12 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 7:25 PM | 40 Comments
  • BTU

    Peabody Energy to sell Wilkie Creek mine in Australia

    • Peabody Energy (NYSE:BTU) +1.8% AH after agreeing to sell its Wilkie Creek Mine in Australia for $20M in cash and the assumption of $55M in liabilities.
    • BTU had agreed to sell the mine in May 2014 for $70M to former billionaire Nathan Tinkler, but the deal collapsed after Tinkler failed to make payments.
    • "We suspect anything and everything is for sale at the right price,” BB&T analyst Mark Levin says of BTU and the rest of the U.S. coal industry, but "the opportunity to get maximum value for these assets is limited.”
     
     
     
     
    | 6:28 PM | 28 Comments

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5:25 p.m.: WBAI +3.1%. BDBD +2.3%. TSRO +2.3%. EXXI +2.2%. SINA +1.9%.
    • Top losers, as of 5:25 p.m.: OTC:ANTH -7.1%. WDFC -5.0%. MDRX -2.6%. MRGE -2.4%. IMKTA -1.3%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:41 PM
  • CHTR

    FCC sets team to review Charter-TWC merger

    • Progress at the FCC -- though maybe not as quick as investors like -- as the agency's chairman, Tom Wheeler, has picked the team to review the Charter-Time Warner Cable merger deal.
    • The agency's general counsel, Jonathan Sallet, will head the team, which also includes the same senior economist (William Rogerson) who worked on the Comcast-TWC deal and the AT&T-DirecTV merger. Former Justice Dept. antitrust attorney Owen Kendler will head the transaction review team.
    • Today: CHTR -1.5%; TWC -1.4%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:14 PM
  • ETSY

    Etsy bucks market selloff, rises 8.6%

    • Two days after making a fresh post-IPO low of $12.80, ETSY has surged in spite of a 1.7% Nasdaq drop. 870K shares have changed hands today; 8.4M were shorted as of June 15.
    • The craft/vintage goods marketplace remains 10% below its $16 IPO price. Its market cap stands at $1.6B.
    • Prior Etsy coverage. SA Etsy analysis.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:56 PM | 1 Comment
  • EOG

    E&P names to struggle in Q2 while refiners reap benefits, analyst says

    • The U.S. E&P industry is "between a rock and a hard place" entering earnings season, Deutsche Bank says, expecting continued headwinds for the group; while momentum has been building for moderate acceleration in activity levels in H2, macro concerns from China to Greece have weighed on crude prices and introduced an “additional layer of uncertainty.”
    • Among the major integrated oils, the firm prefers EOG Resources (EOG -2.5%) and Anadarko Petroleum (APC -2.8%) into Q2 results but cuts its stock price target for Marathon Petroleum (MPC -2.6%) in half to $62.
    • U.S. refiners, on the other hand, continue to defy fears of a collapse in margins, with demand strength and robust gasoline cracks again driving upside to earnings estimates; the firm sees 7% upside on average to current Q2 estimates for the group, with particular strength from Tesoro (TSO -1.2%), Valero (VLO -0.9%) and HollyFrontier (HFC -1.4%).
     
     
     
     
    | 3:49 PM | 12 Comments

  • Broad market decline hits even defensive sectors

    • Notable about today's market selloff - the Dow, Nasdaq, and S&P 500 are lower in the area of 1.5%. - is its spread to the usual ports in a storm. The utilities (XLU -0.6%) and REITs (IYR -0.6%) are outperforming, but still lower even as interest rates slide lower.
    • Any green at all is very difficult to find in a check of the heat map for the S&P 500.
    • Defensive sectors like consumer staples (XLP -1%) and health care (XLV -1.5%) aren't being spared either.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:46 PM
  • DIS

    Nomura: Disney facing tough Q3 comps

    • Nomura says some tough comps are coming next month for Disney (DIS -1.3%), even if it still likes the stock overall.
    • Last year's Q3 (ending in August) benefited from World Cup ad dollars, and consumer products are likely to be skewed to Q4 this year with Star Wars events coming in September and beyond, note analysts Anthony DiClemente and Benjamin Black.
    • The two lowered their Q3 EPS estimate to $1.39, from $1.44 (vs. a consensus of $1.43). Their full-year forecast is unchanged and Nomura's price target on the stock of $125 implies an 8% upside from today's price.
    • Frozen makes for tough comparisons both in consumer products and considering its Q3 international home entertainment release last year. And the pair expects that despite the success of Avengers: Age of Ultron and Inside Out, "given the soft Tomorrowland box office showing, we now expect the Frozen comp to more than offset theatrical. As such, we are lowering our F3Q15E Studio OI growth estimate to -19% YoY."
    • Previously: Disney wins tax break in exchange for $1B theme park investment (Jul. 08 2015)
    • Previously: Disney starts Playmation toy demos, preorders; stock at record high (Jul. 07 2015)
    • Previously: 'Tomorrowland' leads a weaker holiday box office (May. 25 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:21 PM | 4 Comments
  • LGF.A

    Lions Gate working on 'Expendables' mobile game

    • Lions Gate Entertainment (LGF -1.9%) is teaming with Millennium Films and Hong Kong game maker Fifth Journey to develop a mobile game based on aging-hero franchise The Expendables.
    • The game is planned for phones and tablets by the end of 2016, which should coincide with the fourth release in the series. A fifth movie is reportedly planned as well, along with a Fox television show.
    • The first three Expendables films provided progressively declining domestic numbers, but together have grossed more than $786M.
    • Game investment is a bit of a trend for Lions Gate, which has put money into Telltale Games and Next Games and is developing TV shows based on game properties Candy Crush Saga and Titanfall.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:58 PM | 1 Comment
  • SYNT

    Syntel -4.5% on JPMorgan downgrade; healthcare M&A cited

    • Believing healthcare M&A strengthens its belief estimates are too high, JPMorgan has downgraded Syntel (NASDAQ:SYNT) to Underweight, and cut its target by $2 to $48.
    • The firm notes Humana (set to be acquired by Aetna) is a major Syntel client, and thinks the deal could lead discretionary projects to be delayed. It adds 2015 sales guidance implies 7.5%-9.5% Q/Q growth for the rest of the year, compared with average growth of 4.8% over the last 4 years, and that recent news flow about Q2 layoffs could be a sign of weak near-term demand.
    • The IT services provider now trades for 14x a 2016 EPS consensus of $3.11.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:55 PM
  • TSL

    Solar stocks tumble again; TAN -6.3%

    • Solar stocks are seeing big losses once more today. The Nasdaq is down 1.7%, the S&P is down 1.5%, and worries about the economic effects of a Chinese stock market crash are easy to find. Those less concerned make note of China's high savings rate, and the relatively low portion of Chinese household assets invested in equities.
    • The Guggenheim Solar ETF (NYSEARCA:TAN) is now down 32% from its April peak, and roughly flat on the year.
    • Chinese firms Trina (TSL -5.7%), JinkoSolar (JKS -8.9%), Yingli (YGE -4.9%), ReneSola (SOL -6%) China Sunergy (CSUN -5.1%), and Daqo (DQ -4.2%) are adding to yesterday's losses.
    • Major non-Chinese decliners include Canadian Solar (CSIQ -7%), SolarEdge (SEDG -9.9%), Vivint (VSLR -4.4%), and Solar3D (SLTD -8.3%). Enphase is off sharply following a JPMorgan downgrade. SolarEdge and Solar3D are now respectively down 23% and 18% on the week.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:46 PM | 14 Comments
  • ASTI

    Ascent now down 8.5% following sales pre-announcement

    • Up strongly in early trading after pre-announcing Q2 revenue of $2.2M and reiterating full-year sales guidance of $10M-$12M, Ascent Solar (OTC:ASTI) is now singing a very different tune.
    • Shares have touched their 52-week low of $0.46, and are currently just slightly above it. 4.78M shares have been traded, far above a 3-month daily average of 753K.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:56 PM | 4 Comments
  • WAVX

    Wave Systems down 17.3% on strong volume

    • Wave Systems (NASDAQ:WAVX) has plunged on volume of 539K shares, well above a 3-month daily average of 159K.
    • The security software vendor is now down 54% YTD, and is $0.05 above a 52-week low of $0.32. Shares plunged in May after a stock/warrant offering was priced.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:46 PM | 4 Comments
  • TZOO

    Travelzoo up 12.2% on moderate volume

    • Travelzoo (NASDAQ:TZOO) has gradually rallied today on volume of 115K shares. The 3-month daily average is 189K.
    • After the close yesterday, a transaction was disclosed in which chairman Holger Bartel apparently sold 200K shares last Thursday at $10.89 to a trust in the name of his brother, founder and ex-chairman Ralph Bartel. The trust now has 7.43M shares.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:10 PM

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: GAI +36%. HNR +11%. NRX +10%. FES +9%. NSLP +9%. TZOO +8%. NPD +8%. FSYS +8%. LMRK +7%. GAME +7%.
    • Losers: PBM -41%. BLDP -15%. GEVO -13%. RGSE -12%. MTL -12%. NHTC -12%. AXN -12%. CVSL -12%. SFY -10%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:45 PM | 3 Comments
  • CYBR

    CyberArk up 3.1% after NYSE suspends trading (updated)

    • CyberArk (NASDAQ:CYBR) has rallied after the NYSE suspended trading, while citing an unnamed technical issue. Other cybersecurity names are up modestly in the face of a 1.4% Nasdaq drop.
    • The privileged account-protection software vendor posts Q2 results on Aug. 11. Shares +48% YTD.
    • Update (12:34PM ET): The NYSE says the halt isn't due to a "cyber breach." Nonetheless, CyberArk remains up 3.3%.
    • Update 2 (3:12PM ET): The NYSE has resumed trading, and CyberArk is now only up 0.7%. The Nasdaq is down 1.5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:22 PM
  • SWKS

    Chip stocks sell off in early trading; China in focus

    • Chip stocks are underperforming as the Nasdaq registers a 1.2% decline. The Philadelphia Semi Index (SOXX -2.6%) is now down 13% from a June 1 peak of $101.80, and 4% YTD; it's still up 87% from a Nov. 2012 low of $47.58.
    • Plunging Chinese equity markets could be weighing on the group. With retail Chinese investors having set up brokerage accounts en masse over the last year, there are plenty of concerns about the reverse wealth effect of a crash. The Economist reccently downplayed those worries, noting a relatively modest 15% of Chinese household assets are invested in stocks.
    • Major decliners among chip developers include Skyworks (SWKS -4.9%), Qorvo (QRVO -5.6%), InvenSense (INVN -5.6%), NXP (NXPI -4.7%), Freescale (FSL -4%), MoSys (MOSY -9.4%), AppliedMicro (AMCC -5.1%), Cavium (CAVM -3.8%), and Silicon Motion (SIMO -6.4%). SIMO also fell yesterday after favorably adjusting its Q2 sales guidance. Skyworks and Qorvo sold off yesterday morning before rebounding in afternoon trading.
    • Other names tied to the industry that are seeing heavy selling pressure include ARM (ARMH -4%), TowerJazz (TSEM -5.1%), UMC (UMC -4.4%), Veeco (VECO -4.3%), and Axcelis (ACLS -4.6%).
    • Chip ETFs: SMH, XSD, PSI, SOXL, USD, SOXS, SSG
     
     
     
     
    | 11:37 AM | 6 Comments
  • MONIF

    Monitise slides 23% as Visa Europe plans to sell stake

    • Another hit for Monitise (OTC:MONIF), down 23.3% in U.S. trading as Visa Europe says it will sell its 5.3% stake "over time."
    • The companies will keep working together on projects under a three-year pact they formed that ends next March. Visa Inc. (the American provider) already sold its stake in Monitise.
    • Monitise shares fell to their lowest level in six years in London trading. The stock declined again on Monday as it issued yet another sales warning.
    • Previously: Monitise trading down as it issues fourth revenue warning in a year (Jul. 06 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:30 AM | 7 Comments
  • KZ

    KongZhong up 6.5%, forms committee to probe go-private offer

    • KongZhong (NASDAQ:KZ) is up 6.5% as it forms a special committee (in its case, two independent directors) to evaluate the going-private proposal from Chairman/CEO Leilei Wang.
    • Wang and management held about 25% of the company and have offered to buy the rest for $8.56/ADS, which was about a 20% premium over the 30-day average price. The directors, Hope Ni and Xiaolong Li, will have exclusive authority to evaluate and respond to the proposal.
    • The company's trading at $6.54 on Nasdaq, and shares are down about 7% from the time the offer was received.
    • Previously: KongZhong's go-private offer: Too low, or shaky? (Jun. 30 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:04 AM
  • SNAK

    Inventure Foods up 5.6% on Wedbush upgrade

    • Wedbush's Phil Terpolilli has upgraded Inventure Foods (NASDAQ:SNAK) to Outperform, and hiked his target by $3 to $13. "Recent positive recall-related announcements, along with continued positive growth trends in SNAK's other focus brands, make shares increasingly favorable and provide the basis for our upgrade."
    • He thinks Inventure is putting its recall issues behind it, notes the company is seeing strong growth from its focus brands, and sees "ample runway" to improve distribution. "SNAK's fastest growing brands, Boulder Canyon and Fresh Frozen, as well as an improved y/y cost outlook and efficiency improvements, should help the company gradually leverage margin in 2H15 and 2016."
    • Inventure plunged in April after launching a voluntary recall for Fresh Frozen vegetables and Jamba "At Home" smoothie kits. Shares -16% YTD.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:57 AM
  • HOPE

    Wilshire Bancorp takes a breather as sell-sider rings the register

    • Macquarie downgrades Wilshire Bancorp (WIBC -0.9%) to Neutral from Outperform after about a 40% run higher over roughly the last six months.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:55 AM
  • GRUB

    GrubHub up 1% on bullish launch from Northland

    • GrubHub (NYSE:GRUB) is up 1% as Northland Capital Markets launches coverage at Outperform.
    • The company set a $40 price target; shares are currently trading at $31.30.
    • Investors' worries about the company's move into delivery may blow over as GrubHub's "initiatives to reaccelerate profitability" improve, analyst Jeff Houston says. The company's got a deep competitive moat after acquiring Seamless.
    • The firm also sees it as a possible takeout target -- for Uber, Google, TripAdvisor or Priceline.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:50 AM
  • HUBS

    HubSpot up 2.7% after BofA launch, positive Pac Crest note

    • BofA/Merrill has launched coverage on HubSpot (NYSE:HUBS) with a Buy rating and $60 target. Meanwhile, Pac Crest (Overweight rating) has reported positive checks.
    • Needham provided bullish coverage in March. The cloud marketing automation software vendor has now nearly doubled from last October's $25 IPO price, and is up 52% from a post-IPO opening trade of $32.95. Q2 results arrive on Aug. 6.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:46 AM
  • VRTS

    Asset manager paid trade from BAML

    • Bank of America downgrades Virtus Investment Partners (VRTS -4.1%) to Underperform from Neutral, and upgrades Artisan Partners Asset Management (APAM -1.5%) to Neutral from Underperform.
    • Both names have struggled, with VRTS down nearly 50% from a summer-2014 high, and APAM off about 20%.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:44 AM
  • AA

    Alcoa -4% ahead of earnings report after the close

    • Alcoa (AA -4%) tumbles near 52-week lows, with the company set to report quarterly earnings after today's closing bell.
    • BMO analysts aren't getting their hopes up for today's release, saying Alcoa is in "the beginning of one of the weakest pricing environments in years" because of the lags associated with LME aluminum, regional premiums and alumina prices, which suggests the continued sharp decline in each during recent months will hurt Q2 and Q3 results.
    • Other aluminum producers also are lower, as commodities are thrashed today: ACH -10.4%, CSTM -2.2%, CENX -1.5%, KALU -0.1%.
    • Alcoa Q2 earnings previews: I, II
     
     
     
     
    | 10:40 AM | 6 Comments
  • TSLA

    Baird on Tesla: Buy the dip

    • Tesla (TSLA -5%) bulls are getting a gift as two recent downgrades have helped knock the stock price back nearly 10%, says Baird analyst Ben Kallo, reiterating his Outperform rating and $335 price target.
    • The downgrades, he says, do not fully value the lower-priced Model X launch.
    • Previously: Another downgrade for Tesla; stock slips 2% (July 8)
    • Previously: Tesla cut to Hold from Buy at Deutsche Bank (July 7)
     
     
     
     
    | 10:37 AM | 32 Comments
  • STXS

    Stereotaxis up on first Niobe procedure in Japan

    • Thinly traded nano cap Stereotaxis (STXS +7.5%) bucks the market's down day on average volume in response to its announcement that the first procedure with its Niobe ES remote magnetic navigation system has been performed in Japan. The procedure was a cardiac ablation on a patient with ventricular tachycardia (rapid heart beat).
    • Niobe enables the physician to better visualize and control an ablation catheter.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:32 AM
  • TXTR

    Textura up 2.3% following bullish Northland coverage

    • As part of a broader cloud software coverage launch, Northland's Jeff Houston has started Textura (NYSE:TXTR) with an Outperform rating and $40 target.
    • Houston: "Textura’s disruptive technology is modernizing the large and underpenetrated commercial construction industry. The company enjoys first-mover advantage and pricing power. It has a plethora of opportunities to cross-sell and expand both globally and into adjacent markets."
    • He adds that while the functionality of Textura's non-construction payment management (CPM) offerings are in-line with the competition's, they'll be "significantly differentiated once integrated [with the CPM products] with single-sign-on, common database, and sharing information."
    • Benchmark provided bullish coverage in March.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:20 AM
  • CC

    Chemours on the move

    • Chemours (CC -8.1%) is heading back to where it started a week ago. The DuPont spin-off began trading on July 1 - opening up at $13.20 a share.
    • Since then, shares have hit a high of $16.68, but are now on the decline. The stock last traded at $13.68.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:10 AM | 6 Comments
  • PRFT

    Perficient -13.2% on Q2/2015 warning

    • Perficient (NASDAQ:PRFT) now expects Q2 revenue of $108.2M-$109.2M, below a $116.4M consensus. Full-year revenue and EPS guidance has been cut to $455M-$475M and $1.15-$1.25 from $470M-$495M and $1.38-$1.49; consensus is at $480.1M and $1.42.
    • The Q2 outlook is primarily blamed on "unexpected customer delays in contract execution and project startups, including a delay in the ramp up of a large health care engagement."
    • The IT services/consulting firm will post full Q2 results on July 30.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:01 AM
  • MXIM

    Maxim -2.6% on Drexel Hamilton downgrade; Apple share gains cited

    • Drexel Hamilton has downgraded Maxim (NASDAQ:MXIM) to Hold. The firm cites concerns about Apple's high-end smartphone share gains - Maxim depends heavily on sales to Samsung and other Android OEMs.
    • The analog/mixed-signal chipmaker now goes for 18x an FY16 (ends June '16) EPS consensus of $1.79. FQ4 results arrive on July 23.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:50 AM
  • ENPH

    Enphase -8.3% on JPMorgan downgrade

    • JPMorgan has cut Enphase (NASDAQ:ENPH) to Neutral, and lowered its target by $6 to $10.
    • Enphase has made new 52-week lows, and is now down 51% YTD.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:45 AM | 7 Comments
  • LONG

    eLong makes CEO change; shares -5.4%

    • Hao Jiang is replacing Guangfu Cui as eLong's (NASDAQ:LONG) CEO, effective today. Cui will remain on board as a consultant.
    • eLong states Jiang was named CEO "after an extensive search of potential candidates and careful consideration of Mr. Jiang's qualifications, including his extensive experience in and deep knowledge of China's online travel industry, and expertise in product development and software."
    • The CEO change comes less than two months after Expedia announced it had unloaded its 62.4% eLong stake to an investor group that included Ctrip. eLong has joined many other Chinese tech stocks in seeing fresh losses.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:40 AM
  • ASTI

    Ascent pre-announces Q2 sales, reiterates guidance; shares +22.2%

    • Ascent Solar (OTC:ASTI) expects to report Q2 revenue of $2.2M, up over 3x from Q1's $0.66M. Full-year revenue guidance of $10M-$12M is reiterated.
    • CEO Victor Lee: "We remain extremely upbeat for the second half of the year given the increased visibility of our EnerPlex products in a growing number of reputable retailers ... We are also seeing increasing traction in the focused high-value PV market as our lightweight flexible PV panels are entering into a mature development stage for some applications such as PV integrated drones and other high margin PV applications..."
    • Ascent closed yesterday just $0.05 above a 52-week low of $0.45. YTD, shares are still down 43%.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:33 AM | 1 Comment
  • GBSN

    Great Basin Scientific launches Group B Strep test, shares up 17% premarket

    • Nano cap Great Basin Scientific (NASDAQ:GBSN) launches its Group B Streptococcus test in the U.S. Two labs have already converted and more than 40 sites are in active evaluation or are scheduled to evaluate.
    • The test also just received CE Mark clearance in Europe, the company's second, after its test for C. difficile.
    • Shares are up 17% premarket on light volume.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:17 AM | 2 Comments

  • Premarket Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: GBSN +18%. OCLS +10%.
    • Losers: PBMD -15%. JMEI -11%. DANG -9%. JKS -9%. QIHU -8%. SFUN -8%. MOMO -8%. BZUN -8%. CMCM -6%. KTWO -6%. SINA -6%. JD -6%.NQ -6%.YY -6%.VIPS -6%.SID -5%.CSIQ -5%.CLF -5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:12 AM | 19 Comments
  • HOG

    Harley-Davidson downgraded at RBC

    • Harley-Davidson (NYSE:HOG) -1.7% premarket after RBC downgrades shares to Sector Perform from Outperform with a $59 price target, lowered from $66, expecting near-term demand to remain soft with flat operational growth into 2016.
    • RBC is worried that either shipments need to be cut this year or an overstocking situation could develop, as well as increasing competition and the lack of clear potential sales catalysts.
    • Valuation is not too high and the recent buyback limits some downside, so long-term holders can be patient, the firm says, but "improving retail trends... are necessary for new money" to be invested.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:03 AM
  • BHP

    Iron ore tumbles 10% to lowest since at least 2009

    • Iron ore prices plunge to their lowest levels in at least six years, sparked by fears that the rout in China’s stock market could hurt demand while the biggest producers continue to raise output.
    • Ore delivered to Qingdao sank 10% to $44.59/metric ton overnight, the lowest price dating back to May 2009.
    • Iron ore’s 10-day drop started with figures that showed holdings at ports in China rebounded last week while exports from Australia’s Port Hedland climbed to an all-time high., and the slump deepened as China’s stock rout worsened.
    • BHP -3%, RIO -4.2%, VALE -3.2%, CLF -4.8% premarket.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:42 AM | 8 Comments
  • HSBC

    U.K. lenders applaud plan to abolish bank levy

    • Unveiling the summer budget, U.K. Chancellor Osborne says the government will gradually phase out the bank levy over the next six years, replacing it with a new 8% surcharge on profits. The difference? The new charge applies only to U.K. assets, while the bank levy applied to global balance sheets.
    • Osborne may have made the change in response to threats from banks to leave the U.K. because of the levy (which Osborne increased 50% in the last budget).
    • The FTSE 350 banking index is higher by 1.6% following the news. Watching with interest: HSBC, RBS, Barclays (NYSE:BCS), Lloyds (NYSE:LYG), Standard Chartered (OTCPK:SCBFF).
     
     
     
     
    | 8:40 AM | 1 Comment
  • NOAH

    Noah Holdings attempts to prop its stock price

    • The company approves a plan for the purchase of up to $50M of its ADSs over the course of the next year, and says three executive directors intend to purchase ADSs on the open market for their own accounts.
    • "Management is very confident in the Company's direction and long-term value. We continue to see strong momentum in our current businesses and are committed to delivering on our strategic plans."
    • In other news, NOAH is teaming with McKnley Capital Management and a Wharton professor to build a market-leading family office solution for clients.
    • Shares -4.5% premarket after Shanghai slid more than 5% overnight.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:17 AM
  • NYCB

    New York Community Bancorp lower after downgrade

    • After about a 20% run higher from the January lows for New York Community Bancorp (NYSE:NYCB), KBW downgrades the  stock to Underperform.
    • Shares -2.9% in thin premarket action.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:40 AM | 6 Comments
  • TSLA

    Another downgrade for Tesla; stock slips 2%

    • Tesla (NASDAQ:TSLA) gives back a bit more of its recent big run, as Pac Crest's Brad Erickson says the valuation is getting full and downgrades to Sector Weight.
    • He sees fair value for the stock at $293, or just 8% above yesterday's close, meaning a more balanced risk/reward scenario.
    • Shares -2% to $262.44 premarket.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:37 AM | 77 Comments
  • AGO

    Bull back on board with Assured Guaranty

    • BTIG's Mark Palmer downgraded Assured Guaranty (NYSE:AGO) to Neutral from Buy in late June as Puerto Rico's leadership for the first time signaled the possibility of default. He's upgrading back to Buy today with $34 price target, noting adjusted book value is still about double the share price after deducting for estimated PR-related losses.
    • He notes comments from Melba Acosta, head of Puerto Rico's Government Development Bank ahead of a meeting with creditors set for next Monday: "We are not talking about cutting principal or anything like it."
    • Shares +0.9% premarket.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:32 AM | 1 Comment

  • Futures slide as China bubble continues to deflate

    • Despite the best efforts of Beijing to prop up share prices, the Shanghai Composite fell another 5.9% overnight, pulling down Hong Kong and Japan by similar amounts.
    • Europe is enjoying about a 1% bounce after two days of sharp losses.
    • U.S. stock index futures are mostly lower by about 0.65%, but the Russell 2000 (NYSEARCA:IWM) is down 0.9%
    • Gold and crude oil are also seeing small bounces after a rough few sessions, and the 10-year Treasury yield is down four basis points to 2.22%.
